examples.title: Example 1: The Complete Bonus Paradigm
examples.description: Master the full declension of bonus, bona, bonum (good) across all three genders.

paradigm.note: Notice that masculine and neuter share most endings (both use 2nd declension), while feminine uses 1st declension. Dative and ablative plural are identical across all three genders.

examples.title: Example 2: Understanding Agreement (NOT Ending-Matching)
examples.description: The critical concept: adjectives match gender-number-case, NOT endings.

demonstrations.concept: Same endings (both happen to be 2nd declension masculine)

breakdown.agreement: BOTH M nom sg - endings match because both use 2nd decl M pattern

demonstrations.student_reaction: This makes sense - they both end in -us

demonstrations.concept: Different endings (adjective changes to match noun's GENDER, not ending)

breakdown.agreement: BOTH F nom sg - endings look different (-a vs -a, but these are from different declension patterns) BUT they agree in gender/number/case

demonstrations.student_reaction: Wait, why is it 'bona' not 'bonus'? Because bonus is MASCULINE and puella is FEMININE. The adjective must take its FEMININE form.
demonstrations.common_mistake: Thinking 'bonus puella' is correct because you keep the dictionary form
demonstrations.correction: bonus is the MASCULINE dictionary form. For feminine nouns, use bona (the feminine form of the adjective)

breakdown.agreement: BOTH N nom sg - endings match because both use 2nd decl N pattern

demonstrations.student_reaction: Both end in -um, like neuter nouns do

demonstrations.why_wrong: bonus = M nom sg, puella = F nom sg. Different GENDERS means no agreement!
demonstrations.explanation: bona = F nom sg, puella = F nom sg. Same gender/number/case = agreement ✓
demonstrations.key_insight: You must use the form of the adjective that matches the noun's GENDER (and number and case), not match the noun's ending

examples.title: Example 3: Agreement Across Different Cases
examples.description: Watch how adjectives follow their nouns through case changes.

case_demonstrations.observation: The adjective ALWAYS takes the same case as puella, but uses feminine forms from the adjective paradigm
When both are 2nd declension masculine, endings will match
Neuter nominative and accusative are identical, for both adjective and noun

examples.title: Example 4: Attributive vs. Predicate Adjectives
examples.description: Understanding the two ways adjectives function in sentences.

attributive_examples.translation: The good girl sees the road.
attributive_examples.analysis: 'Bona' directly modifies 'puella' - they form a noun phrase 'good girl'
attributive_examples.variant_translation: The good girl sees the road. (same meaning, noun-first order)
attributive_examples.note: Both word orders create attributive relationship

attributive_examples.translation: The girl sees the good road.
attributive_examples.analysis: 'Bonam' modifies 'viam' (both F acc sg) - they form the phrase 'good road'
attributive_examples.emphasis: The adjective agrees with the OBJECT noun here, taking accusative case

predicate_examples.analysis: 'Bona' is separated by 'est' - it describes puella through the linking verb
predicate_examples.note: Still nominative case (agrees with subject), but functions as predicate, not attributive

predicate_examples.analysis: 'Bonae' agrees with 'puellae' (both F nom pl) but functions as predicate adjective
predicate_examples.contrast_with_attributive: Compare: 'Bonae puellae viam vident' = 'The good girls see the road' (attributive)

comparison.attributive: Forms noun phrase WITH the noun (good girl, large war)
comparison.predicate: Describes noun THROUGH linking verb est/sunt (the girl IS good)
comparison.case_note: Predicate adjectives take NOMINATIVE case (agreeing with subject) even though they come after 'est'

examples.title: Example 5: Translating Complex Sentences
examples.description: Practice identifying adjective-noun agreement in full sentences.

sentences.latin: Magnae puellae parvum donum bonō amicō dant.
sentences.translation: The large girls give a small gift to the good friend.
sentences.key_insight: Three different adjective-noun pairs, three different genders, three different cases - but ALL show perfect agreement!

sentences.note: This sentence has BOTH attributive ('multae' modifying 'viae') and predicate ('bonae' describing subject through 'sunt')

sentences.latin: Bona bella parvis terrīs magnam fortunam dant.
sentences.translation: Good wars give great fortune to small lands.
sentences.challenge: Notice 'bona' looks like feminine, but it's actually neuter plural nominative. Context (agreeing with 'bella') tells you this.
sentences.key_insight: You must look at the NOUN to determine the adjective's gender/number/case, not just the ending alone

mistakes.why_wrong: Magnus is masculine, but puella is feminine. They don't agree in gender!
mistakes.explanation: You must use magna (the FEMININE form of magnus) to match puella's feminine gender
mistakes.lesson: Always check noun's gender first, then find the matching adjective form

mistakes.incorrect: Puella magna viam videt. (trying to say: The girl sees the large road)
mistakes.why_wrong: Magna is nominative (matching puella), but if we want it to modify viam (acc), it needs to be accusative too!
mistakes.explanation: Magnam (F acc sg) now agrees with viam (F acc sg) in gender, number, AND case
mistakes.lesson: The adjective must match the case of the noun it modifies, not just the subject

mistakes.error: Confusing neuter plural with feminine singular
mistakes.incorrect_thinking: Seeing 'bona' and assuming it's feminine singular nominative
mistakes.explanation: Bona here is NEUTER PLURAL nominative (agreeing with bella), not feminine singular. Both 'bona' and 'bella' are neuter plural.
mistakes.lesson: Check the NOUN to determine what the adjective must be, not the adjective in isolation

mistakes.incorrect_thinking: If the adjective comes after 'est', it must be different from when it comes before
mistakes.clarification: BOTH mean 'The girl is good' (predicate adjective). Word order is flexible in Latin.
mistakes.contrast: Compare attributive: 'Bona puella vident' OR 'Puella bona vident' = 'The good girl sees' (both attributive, flexible order)
mistakes.lesson: The presence of 'est/sunt' determines predicate function, not word order alone

mistakes.error: Not recognizing agreement with different declensions
mistakes.setup: Later you'll learn 3rd declension nouns like 'rex, regis' (king, masculine)
mistakes.incorrect_thinking: Since rex is 3rd declension, I should use a different adjective form
mistakes.preview: bonus rex (good king) - still uses MASCULINE form (bonus) because rex is MASCULINE
mistakes.explanation: Agreement is by GENDER, not declension. Even though rex doesn't end in -us, it's still masculine, so you use the masculine adjective form
mistakes.lesson: Focus on gender/number/case, not what declension the noun belongs to

examples.title: Example 7: Quick Identification Drills
examples.description: Test your ability to identify agreement patterns.

drills.question: What gender/number/case is 'bonōrum'?
drills.explanation: The -ōrum ending is genitive plural for both masculine and neuter. You'd need to see the noun to know which gender.

drills.question: In 'magnās vias video', what does 'magnās' agree with and why?
drills.answer: Agrees with 'vias' - both are feminine, plural, accusative
drills.explanation: magnās (F acc pl) matches viās (F acc pl) in all three dimensions of agreement

drills.question: Why is 'bona bella' correct but 'bonus bella' wrong?
drills.answer: Bella is neuter plural nominative. You must use bona (neuter plural form), not bonus (masculine singular form)
drills.explanation: Agreement requires matching gender/number/case. Bonus is M sg, bella is N pl - no match!

drills.question: Translate and explain: 'Puella pulchra est'
drills.answer: The girl is beautiful. 'Pulchra' is a predicate adjective (F nom sg, agreeing with puella through 'est')
drills.explanation: Even though pulchra could be attributive ('beautiful girl'), the presence of 'est' makes it predicate ('is beautiful')

drills.question: How would you say 'of the good gifts' (donum, donī, n.)?
drills.explanation: Both neuter genitive plural: bonus → bonōrum (N gen pl), donum → donōrum (N gen pl)

drills.question: What's wrong with 'multī puellae'?
drills.answer: Multī is masculine nom/gen sg OR masculine nominative plural. Puellae is feminine. Gender mismatch!
drills.correct: multae puellae (many girls - both F nom pl)
drills.explanation: Must use the FEMININE form multae to match puellae's gender
